title_sort: john m. rogers to walt whitman, 6 april 1871
title: John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 6 April 1871
text: BrooklynApril 6 1871Dear Father & FriendWhat is the mater[matter] & how do you do and how are you geting[getting] along well I hope I am well now as can be expected after geting[getting] off of a sick bed of four weeks with a fever I wrote you letter some time ago and have not receved[received] no answer as yet so thought I would write again I did not know if you might be SickI have lost a great deal of fleash[flesh] cince[since] you last saw me I am looking quite thin nowI am not doing anything yet but I am gaing[gaining] strength verry[very] fast I should like very much to see you again hoping to hear from you soonI remain your truly good bybyeJohn M. RogersAddressNo 3 Fulton St.BrooklynN.Y.P.S. Write soon for I am ancious[anxious] to hear from you I remain your Affecinate[Affectionate] SonJohn John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 6 April 1871
